script.sh:
---
#!/bin/bash
let b=55
let summe=$a+$b
echo $summe
---

on the command line:
$ let a=5
$ ./script.sh

What is the output of script.sh?

55, not 60.

[jan@md1qk4sc ~]$ cat add.sh
#!/bin/bash
let b=55
let summe=$a+$b
echo $summe
[jan@md1qk4sc ~]$ let a=5
[jan@md1qk4sc ~]$ ./add.sh
55
[jan@md1qk4sc ~]$ export a
[jan@md1qk4sc ~]$ ./add.sh
60
[jan@md1qk4sc ~]$

Execute a command while replacing the shell?

exec <command>

[jan@md1qk4sc ~]$ cat exec1.sh
#!/bin/bash
let a=5
let b=7
export b

echo "exec1 a: $a"
echo "exec1 b: $b"
source ./exec2.sh
echo "exec1 a: $a"
echo "exec1 b: $b"
exec ./exec2.sh
[jan@md1qk4sc ~]$ cat exec2.sh
#!/bin/bash
echo "exec2 a: $a"
echo "exec2 b: $b"

[jan@md1qk4sc ~]$ ./exec1.sh
exec1 a: 5
exec1 b: 7
exec2 a: 5
exec2 b: 7
exec1 a: 5
exec1 b: 7
exec2 a:
exec2 b: 7

When will crond run a command if "day of month" and "day of week" are restricted (i. e. with a number, not an asterisk)?

e. g. 30 4 1,15 * 5 command

crond will run the given command when either field matches the current time.
In the example, the command will be run at 4:30am on the 1st and 15th of each month, plus every Friday.

What are the 3 parts of an rsyslog rule?

- LC_ADDRESS (formatting of addresses)

- LC_IDENTIFICATION (metadata about the locale)

#!/bin/bash

on the command line:

What is the output of script.sh?
60, because the script is not executed but sourced.

The command which was used to run the script.

[jan@md1qk4sc ~]$ cat null.sh
#!/bin/bash
echo $0
[jan@md1qk4sc ~]$ ./null.sh
./null.sh
[jan@md1qk4sc ~]$ /bin/bash null.sh
null.sh
[jan@md1qk4sc ~]$ /bin/bash ./null.sh
./null.sh
[jan@md1qk4sc ~]$ source null.sh
bash

Name a couple of characteristics of IPv6 addresses

- an IPv6 address is hexadecimal
- an IPv6 address consists of 8 segments of 16 bit
- the segments are divided by colons
- leading zeros can be omitted
- all-zero segments can be omitted under certain circumstances, and replaced by two consecutive colons (::)
- only one double colon is allowed

Example: fe80::20c:dead:1337:22fc

Why are shell variables lost after newgrp?

Because newgrp starts a new shell

[jan@lxc-centos ~]$ let a=5
[jan@lxc-centos ~]$ echo $a
5
[jan@lxc-centos ~]$ newgrp wheel
[jan@lxc-centos ~]$ echo $a

[jan@lxc-centos ~]$ exit
exit
[jan@lxc-centos ~]$ echo $a
5
[jan@lxc-centos ~]$

Name the print process in Linux in its order

1) print client (e. g. lpr) puts print job in queue/spooler in /var/spool/ (e. g. 
2) CUPS or LPD fetch the print job from the spool
3) CUPS or LPD transmit the raw data to the print filter
4) filter converts data for printer model and streams it to printer
5) printer prints job
6) print job is deleted from queue

- ftp: 21/tcp
- ssh: 22/tcp+udp
- telnet: 23/tcp+udp
- smtp: 25/tcp+udp
- dns: 53/tcp+udp
- http: 80/tcp+udp
- pop3: 110/tcp+udp
- ntp: 123/tcp+udp
- netbios-ssn: 139/tcp+udp
- imap: 143/tcp+udp
- snmp: 161/tcp+udp
- snmp-trap: 162/tcp+udp
- ldap: 389/tcp+udp
- https: 443/tcp+udp
- igmpv3lite: 465/udp
- shell: 514/tcp+udp
- ldaps: 636/tcp+udp
- imaps: 993/tcp
- pop3s: 995/tcp
